article.description: Louisville's slump appears to be over, just in time for the postseason.
article.headline: Garcia leads Cards with 19 points
article.story: ST. LOUIS (AP) -- Louisville's slump appears to be over, just in time for the postseason. Francisco Garcia had 17 points, six assists and five rebounds, leading a dominant overall performance by the Cardinals (No. 24 ESPN/USA Today, No. 25 AP) in a 75-48 victory over Saint Louis on Wednesday night. Louisville (19-7, 9-6 Conference USA) has won only three of its last nine games, largely due to a rash of injuries, and nearly dropped out of the rankings after rising as high as No. 4 in late January. But the Cardinals have won their last two, also beating No. 20 Memphis on Saturday, and appeared in fine health against the Billikens. "We're back," Garcia said. "Everybody is having fun now. Winning is nice." Louisville has one regular season game remaining, on Saturday at Marquette, before the Conference USA tournament. Kendall Dartez had 12 points and 11 rebounds and Otis George added 13 points for Louisville, which took control with pressure defense that held Saint Louis to 34.9 percent shooting and forced 20 turnovers. For the season, Louisville is holding opponents to 37.3 percent shooting, second-best in the nation. "Their pressure bothered us more than I was hoping it would, not only their pressure on the full court but their pressure on the half court," Saint Louis coach Brad Soderberg said. "They're going to be a tough out in the NCAA tournament." That hounding style on defense forced the patient Billikens to play at Louisville's speed. The Cardinals matched the season high for points against Saint Louis, which has been allowing 58 per game. "We didn't want to play their tempo, we wanted to play our tempo," Garcia said. "We wanted to play fast. Saint Louis has given us trouble in the past and we didn't want that to happen tonight." Saint Louis (15-11, 8-7) had been 11-2 at home and 3-1 against Louisville coach Rick Pitino. But this one was over early as the Billikens absorbed their second lopsided loss in three games, also losing by 25 points at Cincinnati on Feb. 25. "We had a great opportunity, a great setting and quite frankly we laid an egg," Soderberg said. Garcia had all 15 of his first-half points over the final 8:16, scoring on a wide variety of shots, while Louisville's pressure defense forced 12 turnovers and held Saint Louis to 29 percent shooting in the half. Garcia had eight points in Louisville's 15-4 run that gave it a 40-19 halftime lead. "We were relentless with our defense," Pitino said. "I think we were very focused. We were as focused as we have been in some time." An indication of the mismatch: Saint Louis attempted only 17 shots in the first half and didn't get an offensive rebound until 15 minutes were left in the game. The lead grew to as many as 36 points in the second half. The only thing that wasn't working in Garcia's game was the 3-point shot. He was 1-for-11 from long range, making him 3-for-21 the last two games. "I've got to do a better job on my 3-point shots," Garcia said. "I'm not following my shots all the way and I need to work on that." Reggie Bryant had 15 points for Saint Louis. He hit three 3-pointers but was 5-for-14 from the field overall and had six turnovers. The Billikens were without center Tom Frericks, who has a separated shoulder and could miss the rest of the season. Louisville took advantage with a 36-26 rebounding margin, ending a string of five straight games in which it had been outrebounded.
